column1: An atmosphere (from Ancient Greek ἀτμός (atmós) 'vapour, steam', and σφαῖρα (sphaîra) 'sphere') is a layer of gas or layers of gases that envelope a planet, and is held in place by the gravity of the planetary body.
column2: Gas is one of the four fundamental states of matter (the others being solid, liquid, and plasma).

column1: A bag (also known regionally as a sack) is a common tool in the form of a non-rigid container.
column2: Textile is an umbrella term that includes various fiber-based materials, including fibers, yarns, filaments, threads, different fabric types, etc.

column1: A beach is a landform alongside a body of water which consists of loose particles.
column2: Sand is a granular material composed of finely divided rock and mineral particles.

column1: A beard is the hair that grows on the jaw, chin, upper lip, lower lip, cheeks, and neck of humans and some non-human animals.
column2: Hair is a protein filament that grows from follicles found in the dermis.

column1: A body (Latin: corpus) is the physical material of an organism.
column2: Flesh is any aggregation of soft tissues of an organism.

column1: A boot is a type of footwear.
column2: Leather is a strong, flexible and durable material obtained from the tanning, or chemical treatment, of animal skins and hides to prevent decay.

column1: A bottle is a narrow-necked container made of an impermeable material (such as glass, plastic or aluminium) in various shapes and sizes that stores and transports liquids.
column2: Glass is a non-crystalline, often transparent amorphous solid, that has widespread practical, technological, and decorative use in, for example, window panes, tableware, and optics.

column1: A bowl typically is a round dish or container generally used for preparing, serving, or consuming food.
column2: A ceramic is any of the various hard, brittle, heat-resistant and corrosion-resistant materials made by shaping and then firing an inorganic, nonmetallic material, such as clay, at a high temperature.

column1: A box (plural: boxes) is a container used for the storage or transportation of its contents.
column2: Cardboard is a generic term for heavy paper-based products.

column1: Bread is a staple food prepared from a dough of flour (usually wheat) and water, usually by baking.
column2: Flour is a powder made by grinding raw grains, roots, beans, nuts, or seeds.

column1: Bronze is an alloy consisting primarily of copper, commonly with about 12–12.5% tin and often with the addition of other metals (such as aluminum, manganese, nickel or zinc) and sometimes non-metals, such as phosphorus, or metalloids such as arsenic, or silicon.
column2: Copper is a chemical element with the symbol Cu (from Latin: cuprum) and atomic number 29.

column1: Candy, also called sweets (British English) or lollies (Australian English, New Zealand English),[a] is a confection that features sugar as a principal ingredient.
column2: ugar is the generic name for sweet-tasting, soluble carbohydrates, many of which are used in food.

column1: Chocolate is a food product made from roasted and ground cacao seed kernels, that is available as a liquid, solid or paste, on its own or as a flavoring agent in other foods.
column2: The cocoa bean (technically cocoa seed) or simply cocoa (/ˈkoʊ.koʊ/), also called the cacao bean (technically cacao seed) or cacao (/kəˈkaʊ/),[1] is the dried and fully fermented seed of Theobroma cacao, from which cocoa solids (a mixture of nonfat substances) and cocoa butter (the fat) can be extracted.

column1: Clothing (also known as clothes, apparel, and attire) are items worn on the body.
column2: Textile is an umbrella term that includes various fiber-based materials, including fibers, yarns, filaments, threads, different fabric types, etc.

column1: In meteorology, a cloud is an aerosol consisting of a visible mass of miniature liquid droplets, frozen crystals, or other particles suspended in the atmosphere of a planetary body or similar space.
column2: Water vapor, water vapour or aqueous vapor is the gaseous phase of water.

column1: A cocktail is an alcoholic mixed drink.
column2: An alcoholic drink (also called an alcoholic beverage, adult beverage, or simply a drink) is a drink that contains ethanol, a type of alcohol that acts as a drug and is produced by fermentation of grains, fruits, or other sources of sugar.

column1: Concrete is a composite material composed of fine and coarse aggregate bonded together with a fluid cement (cement paste) that hardens (cures) over time.
column2: A cement is a binder, a substance used for construction that sets, hardens, and adheres to other materials to bind them together.

column1: A desk or bureau is a piece of furniture with a flat table-style work surface used in a school, office, home or the like for academic, professional or domestic activities such as reading, writing, or using equipment such as a computer.
column2: Wood is a porous and fibrous structural tissue found in the stems and roots of trees and other woody plants.

column1: Diamond is a solid form of the element carbon with its atoms arranged in a crystal structure called diamond cubic.
column2: Carbon (from Latin: carbo "coal") is a chemical element with the symbol C and atomic number 6.

column1: A door handle or doorknob is a handle used to open or close a door.
column2: A metal (from Greek μέταλλον métallon, "mine, quarry, metal") is a material that, when freshly prepared, polished, or fractured, shows a lustrous appearance, and conducts electricity and heat relatively well.

column1: A flag is a piece of fabric (most often rectangular or quadrilateral) with a distinctive design and colours.
column2: Textile is an umbrella term that includes various fiber-based materials, including fibers, yarns, filaments, threads, different fabric types, etc.

column1: A glacier (US: /ˈɡleɪʃər/; UK: /ˈɡlæsiər, ˈɡleɪsiər/) is a persistent body of dense ice that is constantly moving under its own weight.
column2: Ice is water frozen into a solid state, typically forming at or below temperatures of 0 degrees Celsius or 32 degrees Fahrenheit.

column1: Glass is a non-crystalline, often transparent amorphous solid, that has widespread practical, technological, and decorative use in, for example, window panes, tableware, and optics.
column2: Silicon dioxide, also known as silica, is an oxide of silicon with the chemical formula SiO2, most commonly found in nature as quartz and in various living organisms.

column1: A house is a single-unit residential building.
column2: Wood is a porous and fibrous structural tissue found in the stems and roots of trees and other woody plants.

column1: Ice is water frozen into a solid state, typically forming at or below temperatures of 0 degrees Celsius or 32 degrees Fahrenheit.
column2: Water (chemical formula H2O) is an inorganic, transparent, tasteless, odorless, and nearly colorless chemical substance, which is the main constituent of Earth's hydrosphere and the fluids of all known living organisms (in which it acts as a solvent[1]).

column1: An icicle is a spike of ice formed when water falling from an object freezes.
column2: Ice is water frozen into a solid state, typically forming at or below temperatures of 0 degrees Celsius or 32 degrees Fahrenheit.

column1: Jam refers to a product made of whole fruit cut into pieces or crushed, then heated with water and sugar until it reaches "jelling" or "setting" point, which is achieved through the action of natural or added pectin.
column2: In botany, a fruit is the seed-bearing structure in flowering plants that is formed from the ovary after flowering.

column1: Jeans are a type of pants or trousers made from denim or dungaree cloth.
column2: Denim is a sturdy cotton warp-faced[1] textile in which the weft passes under two or more warp threads.

column1: A lawn is an area of soil-covered land planted with grasses and other durable plants such as clover which are maintained at a short height with a lawnmower (or sometimes grazing animals) and used for aesthetic and recreational purposes.
column2: Poaceae (/poʊˈeɪsiaɪ/) or Gramineae (/ɡrəˈmɪniaɪ/) is a large and nearly ubiquitous family of monocotyledonous flowering plants commonly known as grasses.

column1: A lens is a transmissive optical device which focuses or disperses a light beam by means of refraction.
column2: Glass is a non-crystalline, often transparent amorphous solid, that has widespread practical, technological, and decorative use in, for example, window panes, tableware, and optics.

column1: A mirror or looking glass is an object that reflects an image.
column2: Glass is a non-crystalline, often transparent amorphous solid, that has widespread practical, technological, and decorative use in, for example, window panes, tableware, and optics.

column1: Money is any item or verifiable record that is generally accepted as payment for goods and services and repayment of debts, such as taxes, in a particular country or socio-economic context.
column2: Paper is a thin sheet material produced by mechanically or chemically processing cellulose fibres derived from wood, rags, grasses or other vegetable sources in water, draining the water through fine mesh leaving the fibre evenly distributed on the surface, followed by pressing and drying.

column1: The ocean (also the sea or the world ocean) is the body of salt water that covers approximately 70.8% of the surface of Earth and contains 97% of Earth's water.
column2: Water (chemical formula H2O) is an inorganic, transparent, tasteless, odorless, and nearly colorless chemical substance, which is the main constituent of Earth's hydrosphere and the fluids of all known living organisms (in which it acts as a solvent[1]).

column1: In cuisine, an omelette (also spelled omelet) is a dish made from beaten eggs, fried with butter or oil in a frying pan (without stirring as in scrambled egg).
column2: Eggs are laid by female animals of many different species, including birds, reptiles, amphibians, a few mammals, and fish, and many of these have been eaten by humans for thousands of years.

column1: Pastry is baked food made with a dough of flour, water and shortening (solid fats, including butter or lard) that may be savoury or sweetened.
column2: Flour is a powder made by grinding raw grains, roots, beans, nuts, or seeds.

column1: A penny is a coin (pl. pennies) or a unit of currency (pl. pence) in various countries.
column2: A metal (from Greek μέταλλον métallon, "mine, quarry, metal") is a material that, when freshly prepared, polished, or fractured, shows a lustrous appearance, and conducts electricity and heat relatively well.

column1: A tablet (also known as a pill) is a pharmaceutical oral dosage form (oral solid dosage, or OSD) or solid unit dosage form.
column2: A medication (also called medicament, medicine, pharmaceutical drug, medicinal drug or simply drug) is a drug used to diagnose, cure, treat, or prevent disease.

column1: Plastics are a wide range of synthetic or semi-synthetic materials that use polymers as a main ingredient.
column2: A polymer (/ˈpɒlɪmər/;[4][5] Greek poly-, "many" + -mer, "part") is a substance or material consisting of very large molecules called macromolecules, composed of many repeating subunits.

column1: A roof is the top covering of a building, including all materials and constructions necessary to support it on the walls of the building or on uprights, providing protection against rain, snow, sunlight, extremes of temperature, and wind.
column2: Roof shingles are a roof covering consisting of individual overlapping elements.

column1: The sea, connected as the world ocean or simply the ocean, is the body of salty water that covers approximately 71 percent of the Earth's surface.
column2: Water (chemical formula H2O) is an inorganic, transparent, tasteless, odorless, and nearly colorless chemical substance, which is the main constituent of Earth's hydrosphere and the fluids of all known living organisms (in which it acts as a solvent[1]).

column1: Snow comprises individual ice crystals that grow while suspended in the atmosphere—usually within clouds—and then fall, accumulating on the ground where they undergo further changes.
column2: Water (chemical formula H2O) is an inorganic, transparent, tasteless, odorless, and nearly colorless chemical substance, which is the main constituent of Earth's hydrosphere and the fluids of all known living organisms (in which it acts as a solvent[1]).

column1: A spoon is a utensil consisting of a small shallow bowl (also known as a head), oval or round, at the end of a handle.
column2: A metal (from Greek μέταλλον métallon, "mine, quarry, metal") is a material that, when freshly prepared, polished, or fractured, shows a lustrous appearance, and conducts electricity and heat relatively well.

column1: Steel is an alloy made up of iron with typically a few tenths of a percent of carbon to improve its strength and fracture resistance compared to other forms of iron.
column2: Iron (/ˈaɪərn/) is a chemical element with symbol Fe (from Latin: ferrum) and atomic number 26.

column1: A table is an item of furniture with a raised flat top and is supported most commonly by 1 or 4 legs (although some can have more), used as a surface for working at, eating from or on which to place things.
column2: Wood is a porous and fibrous structural tissue found in the stems and roots of trees and other woody plants.

column1: A wall is a structure and a surface that defines an area; carries a load; provides security, shelter, or soundproofing; or, is decorative.
column2: Drywall (also called plasterboard, wallboard, sheet rock, gypsum board, buster board, custard board, and gypsum panel) is a panel made of calcium sulfate dihydrate (gypsum), with or without additives, typically extruded between thick sheets of facer and backer paper, used in the construction of interior walls and ceilings.

column1: Water (chemical formula H2O) is an inorganic, transparent, tasteless, odorless, and nearly colorless chemical substance, which is the main constituent of Earth's hydrosphere and the fluids of all known living organisms (in which it acts as a solvent[1]).
column2: Hydrogen is the chemical element with the symbol H and atomic number 1.

column1: A wig is a head or hair accessory made from human hair, animal hair, or synthetic fiber.
column2: Hair is a protein filament that grows from follicles found in the dermis.

column1: Wine is an alcoholic drink typically made from fermented grapes.
column2: A grape is a fruit, botanically a berry, of the deciduous woody vines of the flowering plant genus Vitis.

column1: A wire is a flexible strand of metal.
column2: A metal (from Greek μέταλλον métallon, "mine, quarry, metal") is a material that, when freshly prepared, polished, or fractured, shows a lustrous appearance, and conducts electricity and heat relatively well.

column1: Yogurt (UK: /ˈjɒɡət/; US: /ˈjoʊɡərt/,[1] from Turkish: yoğurmak, also spelled yoghurt, yogourt or yoghourt) is a food produced by bacterial fermentation of milk.
column2: Milk is a nutrient-rich liquid food produced by the mammary glands of mammals.
